title: Slow byzantium tests
body:
### What is wrong?

Here are the slowest 50 byzantium tests.

The slowest 20 of those combine for 30 minutes worth of test running.  Currently the whole suite takes about 45 minutes to run which is right at the threshhold for travis-ci's maximum runtime for a single test run.


### How can it be fixed

I'm thinking that we split the byzantium tests into two runs, one with the 20 slowest tests and then another with all the rest.
We may also want to profile those test runs to see where time is being spent. I'd be willing to bet there's low hanging fruit there that would improve performance significantly.

## Some info about the slowest tests
I'm going to profile those tests and summarize my findings here to see if there's anything we can do to make them run faster

### static_Call50000_sha256:Byzantium:0 ([profiling stats](http://sprunge.us/cTeC))
Seems to spend most of its time in `Trie.get()` and `rlp.decode()` (all called from `sstore()`). Will have to look into py-trie and py-rlp to see if there's anything we could improve there; saving for later. Went from 201s to 154s (locally) with a6b834f22a8db8c869a1cdc8fa1fd57447529af5

### static_Call50000_rip160:Byzantium:0 ([profiling stats](http://sprunge.us/PVRL))
Went from 145s to 122s with a6b834f22a8db8c869a1cdc8fa1fd57447529af5

### static_LoopCallsThenRevert:Byzantium:0 ([profiling stats](http://sprunge.us/hiHC))
Biggest offenders: `State._get_account()` and `rlp.decode()`. My _get_account() changes (a6b834f22a8db8c869a1cdc8fa1fd57447529af5) seem to have cut its runtime from 35s to 24s (locally)

### static_Call50000_identity:Byzantium:1 ([profiling stats](http://sprunge.us/PSOG))
Similar to the one above. Went from 79s to 66s locally

# `rlp.decode()`

Short term solution would be a simple caching layer.  Longer term solution would be to re-implement the RLP library in cython.

# `State._get_account()`

Caching account state for read operations should yield some speed ups with low implementation effort.  (Left a comment in the open pull request saying this same thing.)

# `Trie.get()`

Everytime I'v profiled things, the `trie` library (which I wrote) is high on the list of things that end up consuming a lot of time.

#169 improved some of those slow tests, and https://github.com/gsalgado/py-evm/tree/account-cache has some extra changes we decided not to merge at this point as we don't think the improvements outweigh the extra complexity

As an experiment, we could skip the tests that take more than 60s in the regular travis builds, and then run them on a daily travis cron job? If we start seeing failures on the cron job too often we can easily go back to running even the slowest tests on every build

> As an experiment, we could skip the tests that take more than 60s in the regular travis builds, and then run them on a daily travis cron job? If we start seeing failures on the cron job too often we can easily go back to running even the slowest tests on every build

I like this a lot.  I'll see about setting it up today (since I'm already mucking with a bunch of repositories today)
